MAIL Dear Sir, With reference to our conversation of 8th October, 1944, the Company as well as C.C. Bechtel McCone and the employees of both Companies have been using the Army Post Tor mail to and from the United States and Canada. The use of the army facilities was offered and accepted approximately eighteen months ago because of the saving in time over regular mail service. It is believed that the saving in time is still large and accordingly, the Companies wish to continue to use the Army Post Office for both their own and their employees’ mail, provided the facilities are continued, until regular mail service again becomes normal. our use of the A.P.O. has been raised by Major Estes of the Persian Gulf Command and in order to answer Major Estes, there are certain points on which I will appreciate your advice. These are: regular internal United States rates are charged and United' States stamps are used, such stamps being obtainable from the A.P.O. Since it may possibly be considered that the use by the Companies and their employees of this service results in a loss of revenue by the Bahrein Post Office, I will appreciate your advice if there is any objection to our continued use of this service. for transmittal. The size of package accepted and the method of forwarding depends upon the availability of space at any given time. Normally, the Army forwards packages of one pound and under by air and packages over one pound by sea mail. However, under present operating conditions all packages are being for warded by air. The question of any claims which might result from (1) For all mail handled by the Army Post Office, (2) In addition to letters, the Army accepts packages We desire to continue to use the A.P.O. service for our employees in the forwarding of packages, not only because2 October 17, 1944. of the shorter time involved but because experience has shown that parcels forwarded by regular mail have been subjected to a large amount of pilferage. It is our understanding that under defence regula tions, all goods of non-Bahrein origin exported require an export permit. I will appreciate your advice as to whether you will require application for export permit on all packages wnich may contain goods of non-Bahrein origin or whether the permit*on certain items or size of package may be waived. It is my opinion that virtually all of the packages contain sou venirs, bric-a-brac, rugs, etc., from this area. (3) Incoming packages as well as the mail have been coming directly from the Army Post Office at Muharraq to Awali without customs examination. The volume and size of these packages has been relatively small and the packages usually contain^ clothing and other personal effects which are in short supply in Bahrein. The subject of customs examination has been discussed with Mr. G.W.R. Smith and he is of the opinion t/iat since the volume is small and it may be expected that availability of A.P.O. service will end within a reasonable length of time, no appreciable loss in customs revenue will result in our continuation of the present practice. I will appreciate your advice that there is no objection to our con- inuation of tne present method of handling incoming packages. Yours very truly, For W.P. I consider it would be very unwise to insist on all letters passing through the Bahrain Post Office for the delay in receiving lecters would have a very serious effect on the morale of the American workmen in particular those employed on the hundred octane plant construction. Firstly the question of censorship of letters and packets and secondly the customs examination of packets. I advise that the whole procedure now in force be permit ted to continue except that air postal packets should have a weight limitation imposed of one pound. titleInfo.title: 'File No. 17/14 USE OF UNITED STATES ARMY POST OFFICE FACILITIES FOR BAPCO & ARAMCO.'

physicalDescription.extent: The papers are arranged in approximate chronological order from the front to the rear of the file.

Foliation: the main foliation sequence (used for referencing) commences at the front cover with 1 and terminates at the back cover with 55; these numbers are written in pencil, are circled, and are located in the top right corner of the recto side of each folio. An additional foliation sequence is also present in parallel between ff 2-29; these numbers are also written in pencil, but are not circled, and are located in the same position as the main sequence. Pagination: the file notes at the back (ff 49-54) have been paginated using pencil.

mods.abstract: The file comprises correspondence relating to the use by the Bahrain Petroleum Company (BAPCO) and Arabian American Oil Company (ARAMCO) of the United States Army Post Office in Bahrain to send mail and parcels to the United States and Canada.The correspondence discusses permission the existing postal services from Bahrain to the USA through the Indian Postal Service, and the high costs and frequent delays which the service was afflicted by, and attempts to improve the service following the closure of the US Army Post Office at Bahrain in September 1945.The correspondence is primarily between the Political Agent at Bahrain (Tom Hickinbotham, Cornelius James Pelly, Arnold Crawshaw Galloway), Political Resident in the Persian Gulf (Charles Geoffrey Prior, William Rupert Hay) and Secretary to the External Affairs Department of the Government of India (Olaf Kirkpatrick Caroe).A series of file notes which were maintained as a record of the correspondence in the volume can be found at folios 49-54.
